Octopath Traveler 2 is a game that knows what it is, for better or worse.

The art style is the real winner here: nostalgic without being lazy and very reminiscent of FF6 for me. The music is excellent, which helps, because you’ll spend a lot of time listening to it while wandering through the game’s oddly disjointed world. Fantasy Mongolia? Fantasy Wild West? Sure, why not. It’s not seamless, but it’s charming in its own way.

Eight hours in, I’ve got four characters, all from the eastern continent, and their chapter 1s wrapped up. Some stories are pretty standard fantasy fare, but only one of those four origin stories has really piqued my interest so far. The disjointed narratives don’t bother me much: if anything, the idea of eight strangers crossing paths adds to the adventure vibe. That said, a few of these arcs could use a little more depth.

The turn-based combat is solid, with the weakness/break system an interesting addition. The Boost system takes a second to click, but once it does, battles feel tactical instead of tedious. The job system seems like it’s got potential, but I’ve barely touched it beyond the starter roles.

The Path Actions are a mixed bag. Hiring and 'enticing' NPCs to fight alongside you in a limited capacity (with bonus passive effects) are clever touches, but information gathering and bribing NPCs mostly just reveals low-tier loot or some lore, so far. Limiting the 'learned skills' capacity to 5 seems for one particular character seems a little restrictive, but maybe that changes. Still, the lack of hand-holding is refreshing, even if some of the character motivations feel a little underdeveloped.

All in all, it’s a great JRPG with room to grow. The combat and presentation are strong, but the story and world design are, 8 hours in, a little lacking. If the second halves of these character arcs deliver, this could be something special. If not? Well, it’s still pretty to look at and fun to play.

Early Verdict: 8/10—worth playing, but not without its quirks.

This is a superb turn-based JRPG and an amazing leap forward from the first Octopath game. Experience eight different storylines for each of your party members, and the plot then culminates with a cool final boss battle. The music and graphics are gorgeous and a throwback to the best of the 16-bit generation RPGs. I had absolutely no glitches or crashes and the game was rock solid all the way through. I found the difficulty pretty easy until the final boss and secret extra boss, which were both quite challenging. My overall playtime was about 60 hours for the main story and about 77 hours for 100% completion.

5/5. I don’t normally leave reviews, but I felt compelled to do it for Octopath II because of how incredible my experience was playing it. For the record, playing it on the steam deck (which is flawless). Spoiler free.

Good:
- The game is very beautiful. I mean this in every way. The graphics are gorgeous and immersive, although I am sure I have a little nostalgia goggles by comparing it to JRPGS in 2000s. I especially liked the Crestlands (mountain autumn vibe). The writing is good, albeit a bit uneven throughout the game and there are a few moments that stick out to me even when not playing. And the music is truly incredible, on the level of Skyrim or morrowind. The haunting and eerily beautiful nighttime music especially stands out.
- There are numerous little details in the graphics, the writing, and even the music that go towards the theme of the “Dawn” and other themes. The details really sell the the world and make the game stand out. I wish all games were treated the same. For example, little side quests that re completely optimal will tie back to the main story in a way that is touching and beautiful.
- Characters. The main characters are likeable and sympathetic. It’s easy to sit in their shoes and get drawn into the story. I love the banter between party (wish there was more) and each characters story. You will naturally favor some over the others (I like Temenos and throne the most). Even voice acting is good.
- Immersive world. I liked how you naturally learned about the world through the cutscenes and little details and chats with NPCs. I hated that there are minimal books or things that flesh out the world (like I have no clue even after 70 hours if the eastern continent is united or not). World generally made sense and world-building was consistent throughout. Lots of interesting side quests and content as you progress.
- Hard to articulate, but it’s very smooth and easy to pick up and play for 15 minutes at a time (or longer for that matter). Very friendly for gamers like me that are constantly moving and doing things.
- Very good value. It’s a long game and it actually keeps you sucked in. I paid $23.99 and anticipate playing for about 100 hours.
Okay:
- Combat is fun and immersive but it can get a little repetitive after a while. The main theme is creativity and combos. I liked the creativity of having multiple classes and the combos between characters and their latent abilities and ultimate powers. It’s immensely satisfying to experiment and find things that work. But it can be annoying to have to try to calculate every possible combo. I found myself skipping a lot of battles after like 40 hours.
Bad:
- Uneven. Some plots felt a little rushed at times or simply didnt really speak to me as much as others. No plot was bad, but some chapters could probably be categorized as filler. 
- Little things broke some of the immersion. Like, you will never see other stuff party members during a cutscene in the main story for each character, let alone hear theme chime in. Octopath Traveler 2 is not a lazy sequel, it improves almost every aspect of OCT1, while still being different enough to keep the first game interesting.
Don't let the old school art fools you ! The J-RPG turn based combat system is modernized.
The gameplay has new mechanics, and all the classes have been rebalanced and fixed on many aspects.
Crazy synergies are back.
Characters are a lot more flexible in battle, than they were in OCT1, but the first game keeps its charm and uniqueness in that regard, and is easier to understand (OCT2 is a bit complexified).

The 2D graphics are smoother and a bit less pixel art, there are now 3D effects and other visual ones like blur, which makes the game pretty, but not to everyone's taste.
It's different enough to enjoy OCT1 and OCT2 graphics diffently.
The musics are truly incredible, and the story still very touching.
The concept is still the same: you still have the freedom to go where you want and do the quests in the order you wish.

There is only one thing that disappoints: the challenge.
OCT2 is a lot easier than OCT1, so I really advice to play a low lvl run, avoiding too many random fights and exp grinding.
Don't pay attention to the quest level requirements, they are very over-exagerated, I was 20 levels lower than those most of the time and still doing fine !
Despite all the qualities this game has, I enjoyed OCT1 more as it was harder, on top of being a complete new discovery.
(But there are hard difficulty mods available, although I haven't tested them).

Both games are excellent and different enough to be complementary, I highly recommand to play OCT1 first as it is also less complicated gameplay wise.

You've seen who it's made by. You've seen the big boy reviews. I promise you this game will not dissapoint you, if you're even slightly interested or intrigued by the JRPG genre, and I genuinely cannot praise this game enough.

For starters. It's Square Enix, and this is the 2nd game in the series. Besides the gorgeous graphics, the amazing gameplay, and the wonderful soundtrack, they've pretty much polished up every aspect of the game and made it better in every way compared to the first installment. (this isn't to say the first game is awful, it really isn't and you should definitely play it if you enjoyed this one)
The only thing that could deter people would either be the random enemy encounters (which is why I mentioned you should be a bit intrigued by the JRPG genre) or how the story pacing goes. Each character has a set number of chapters, each chapter is "locked" behind a specific level requirement. You COULD go underleveled, but it will be harder to beat the aforementioned chapter. So you might end up in a situation where you'd do the 2nd chapter of every character in your party, instead of doing all X chapters of a specific characters, and progressing their full story all at once. This way of storytelling has it's own charm, so don't feel too worried about it.

In-between chapters, you'll mostly find yourself doing either side quests, or wandering around enemy areas to level up your party. Besides that, what you should do is explore the map. There are hidden chests around every part of the map, and some contain strong/unique equipment that could easily mitigate the underleveled issue. Gear is really strong, so if you're bored, you should definitely explore the open-world and do side quests. If you aren't the exploring type, for the most part shop equipment will suffice assuming you're properly leveled.

The characters system is what makes Octopath stand out, as you're given the choice to pick between 8 travelers, each with their respective skill-set and role. Don't spend too much time worrying about who you choose, you'll end up recruiting all of them at one point. Parties are made of 4 characters, so depending on how you decide to level up your characters, you might end up having to level up 2 separate parties from the ground up. Alternatively, just keep 2 overleveled characters, and swap 2 underleveled characters, and level them up like that. It's up to you. While the characters themselves don't interact a lot between each other in their respective main stories, they have a lot of side banter that happens during a character's specific chapter. Say.. the Warrior experiences a scary moment in his chapter, and one of the party members offers to help during the "banter dialogue". Besides that, a few side stories exist where 2 characters end up working with each other, and during the final chapter of the game you'll see them all together in the story.

The soundtrack is 10/10, nothing to comment here.
The story might be a bit confusing at times, or have obvious plot twists, but overall I'd say it's a 9/10. Every character has a refreshing story that is different compared to everyone else's.
The HD-2D graphics is something that started with the Octopath series, but has been expanded upon by now in other games. Still extremely gorgeous.
The voice acting for this game has a few small hiccups sometimes, and you will notice it especially on a specific side character, but overall it's great, and they've worked with pretty big names this time around. You might definitely recognize some of them.

The combat is more complicated than it might seem at first. Enemies have different weaknesses. Find the weakness, keep hitting them with what they're weak against, and you'll end up stunning them. While simple on paper, every character has a different role, and a different type of "action" in combat. The Apothecary is able to make concoctions using items found in shops or while exploring. The Merchant can't do that, but the Merchant can summon NPC's from around the map, each with their own skills. So on and so forth.
Side note for the tryhards out there, Square Enix has the tendency to hide final, optional boss fights that legit just feel unfair to play against. Have fun.

The open-world map is pretty big. You have a lot of terrain to cover and explore, and there are countless places you should/have to visit, either they be cities, caves, hidden entrances to whatever shenanigans the devs were thinking in that moment, etc. Every part of the map is part of a "region", and every region is different from each other. Deserts, actual Cities (not small towns), jungles, mountains, and many more.

Overall, the story is 9/10, soundtrack 10/10, graphics 10/10, quality-of-life 8/10, gameplay/combat 10/10. Play the game, it IS worth every cent.

Octopath Traveler II is a JRPG masterpiece that should not be missed by anyone who considers themselves a fan of JRPGs. 

The 10/10 soundtrack alone makes this game worth playing. There are many modern quality-of-life features that alleviate annoyances in older JRPG's. The boss difficulty is on the higher side and the game features what I consider the most challenging and enjoyable superboss I’ve ever encountered in the genre, even tougher than Penance from FFX or any of the superbosses from Etrian Odyssey.

The pacing is quite unique as you’re constantly switching between the stories of different characters instead of following a single main story.
While this approach makes for a less emotionally impactful narrative overall, it keeps the gameplay fresh and varied since there’s always another character chapter available, and it’s easy to enjoy the game in short bursts (like spending 30 minutes to quickly finish another chapter). The open-world nature is also a standout feature in this regard since it allows you to explore the world freely and choose the next story chapter freely (as long as your party is leveled enough for it).

Visually, the game also stands out. The unique and beautiful HD-2D art style is complemented with vibrant colorful lighting in the overworld and flashy animations in battle. Especially on the OLED Steam Deck, which I used for most of my playthrough, the colors really pop and the game ran flawlessly on it too.

If you’re a fan of particularly great soundtracks, enjoy challenging boss fights, and are looking for something fresh in the JRPG genre, then buying this game is a no-brainer.

A very enjoyable and charming jRPG.

The negatives - it has a bunch of standard jrpg quirks:
- the typical spam of random and annoying encounters as You traverse the world, this become extra annoying when (for whatever reason) You need to move through a low level zone with Your high level party (yes You can just 'flee' or just spam aoe attacks, but still it's just an annoying interruption more often than not)
- again in typical fashion You are expected to grind some...this is inevitable if You want to beat the game to it's fullest, but even if You just want to finish the stories of characters that are not part of Your 'main party' just because the story expects You to use a 'path action' that is gated behind a certain character level.
In short the game expects You to level all 8 companions fairly evenly and if You prefer a play-style (like me) where You build a favorite squad and don't really care to min-max all the side characters then You will hit a wall at some point...
Side note on the secret boss (which I did not finish at least for now...maybe will return to it at some point) is the peak of that approach, most of the strategies revolve around a cheese tactic around items/specific character skills, so if You never planned for that then You need at least couple of hours of level/item farming to be prepared. It's not bad per se, it's just something to be aware for all the completionists out there :) (my backlog of games is too long to do that for now)

Now the positives: 
- if You enjoyed OT 1 - You will enjoy this one, it's more of the same basically, no massive changes (which is good and bad I guess)
- the graphical style is beautiful, the environments, the boss design, it's just top tier, especially if You have that retro love in You
- the music is fantastic, I honestly feel it's one of the best instrumental music available in modern games
- story is really interesting and although has it's 'cringy' moments (I'm sorry maybe it's just the fact I couldn't really connect with a furry-kiddo Ochette...) it culminates in an interesting fashion and has a satisfying ending
- game-play is good, it's simple enough that You can jump into it fairly quickly and understand the mechanics (shield/brake/vulnerability system and damage types etc) but still gives You enough job/secondary job/item/skill/passive skill combinations that You can play around different strategies to make it interesting and unique

In short - if You are an jRPG fan - no brainer, go for it, it's worth it. For anyone else, You should definitely try it if You have any craving for an interesting story, beautiful music and rpg elements.

This isn't like any game I've ever seen. For some this may be great, but it won't be for everybody. This is a grand adventure. It's very heavy on exposition and story telling. If you enjoy this sort of thing and if you have a bit of patience, you will have a good time. Make no mistake: I'm nowhere in the game. Mild spoiler warning, but: You start the game alone and you have to get by with what you have. Then you have to get through the first hurdles, which you're at times ill prepared for. If you can find your way, you can start adding party members. This is not straightforward because many paths are softcapped, so way too high for your level. You have to find a survivable route, which makes for a tedious start. You think it gets easier then, but no. Every party member has an origin story. If you play that, you are back at one character at level 1. Then you have to scrounge for what resources and levels the best you can and finish up. Then you can continue with a bigger party. It's not THAT hard if you're patient, but some characters are really bad at solo fights, or, maybe I'm terrible at the game. Either way, the solo fights can take ages. On the other hand, at 22 hours in, I've not seen much combat or done anything that's actually that hard. If you're prepared for this, it's a good game. I'm still playing it after all. Having just a thumbs up or down doesn't do it justice: It has to be your cup of tea. *I've seen a fair bit now and there is a lot to do. The downside is the adventure becomes quite disjointed and the game is understandably, not very well balanced. The early quests for any later characters you might pick up are way too easy. On the other hand, you're underleveled for the main quest, unless you find other things to do. This is a bit of a fuss, but, you won't run out of stuff to do soon.

I suppose my criteria for a good story has increased with time, age, and an increase in data available -- but this game definitely feels new-old school and if that's what you're after it will very, much scratch the itch. I wish, sometimes, the stories were a bit more in depth and the gameplay was a bit more in depth, too, but overall I think the game achieved what it meant to do. I've always been hesitant when it came to checking out Octopath Traveler since I mostly play story focused JRPGs and haven't heard almost any positive opinions when it came to the first game's story. So I ended up skipping that game. Now, I haven't heard many favorable things about Octopath Traveler 2's story either, but I did hear that apparently it at least improved upon the first title. And as I suddenly found myself in a mood for a more gameplay focused experience, I decided to give 2 a shot.

Unfortunately, as it turns out, this is one of the few RPGs in my life I actually had to drop without completing out of sheer boredom.

As I said, my expectations for the storytelling were low. On top of that, I usually prefer a more focused narrative centered around a main party of characters with strong character dynamics. So something like Octopath, which is split among 8 characters, each with their own story, already doesn't sound too appealing to me. But I heard that the character interactions were improved in 2, so I had at least a little bit of hope.

But even with my already low expectations, I was still left disappointed. The individual stories vary wildly in tone and atmosphere, making it difficult for me to get invested and immersed. The wide array of character backgrounds doesn't make the world feel like a single large diverse world to me, instead it makes it feel chopped up into separate, incohesive chunks, each with their own theme.

The plot of the individual character stories is played very much by the book and predictable. Predictable doesn't mean bad of course, but the execution is also mostly extremely basic. The dialogues, albeit well localized, are just... dull. Reading them sometimes felt like reading dialogues from a fairy tale for kids. It gets especially bad during dialogues of less important characters like random villagers. Not that the dialogue and characterization of side and main characters is much better. Again, not bad, just really basic and uninteresting.

The character dynamics between the main characters are also pretty much non-existant. There are a few dialogues you can trigger when reaching certain towns or story points that involve 2 characters from the party talking to each other. These are the only interactions between them that I've encountered so far. And they are in most cases just as simple and dull short conversations as the rest. Nothing that would even remotely get me emotionally attached to the cast.

Keep in mind that I've only played chapters 1 & 2 for all characters, as well as chapters 3 or even 4 for those I enjoyed the most. I'm sure there might be more interesting content later, but I had to give up at this point.

Now I've spent most of the time complaining about the story, which I didn't really have high expectations for. But the gameplay side disappointed me even more, for a lot simpler reasons. Perhaps the biggest culprit is the completely all over the place balance. Much like the storytelling, the gameplay challenge Octopath offers also feels totally incoherent to me. I don't think I've had a single fair encounter during all those hours I played. All the time I was either completely overleveling the enemy, making the fight a joke. Or I was completely overleveled by the enemy because I stumbled into a high level area, making the fight near impossible mathematically.

I think the main reason for that is the split across 8 different stories. This resulted in the levels of my party being spread far and wide, making it impossible to really get a fair fight since my first few characters were massively overleveling any immediate story content. You could theoretically look for a challenge in some higher level optional areas, or when rushing a single character's story all the time, but I'm not a fan of a game's difficulty being reliant on the player intentionally handicapping themselves or having to look for enemies of a specific level to have a challenge. Not having higher difficulty options also didn't help I suppose.

But most of my complaints involve the words "dull" and "boring", which are of course entirely subjective impressions and matters of taste, so your mileage may vary. I simply found out that Octopath's formula of both gameplay and storytelling simply isn't fun for me.

I want to start with saying that the story and gameplay are good, the problem is how the two don't work together and causes jarring discrepancies between the gameplay and the story.

From a gameplay perspective, this is mostly just Bravely Default's gameplay system, turn-based party combat since you'll have a party of 4 for the vast majority of the game unless you're actively trying a challenge run with less party members. As in Bravely Default, the gameplay is pretty good.

However, the story NEVER acknowledges that you're not just one character but a party. Each character's story acts as if the party didn't exist and that that character was alone. This shows in how there's no interaction between the characters during the story and the story even acts as if fights that are happening are 1v1 fights and, outside some fights involving certain characters whose path actions let's them duel NPCs, it's actually a fight between the enemy and your party which is insanely jarring. There are some interactions between party members in the form of party banter, small chats between generally 2 party members which sometimes somewhat relates to the current story but is often just for light hearted fun. There's also a handful of crosspaths, stories involving 2 specific characters, but they're short and there's not a lot of them.

Then there's also the world building which brings further inconsistencies with some NPCs acting like the world is big and it's a big deal to traverse a continent and even more so to cross the ocean between the 2 continents while the story and sidequests often act like the fast travel instant teleport is cannon. For example, you have a story that tells you an arms shipment is going to happen soon and needs to be stopped, but the place between where you learn of it and the place where the trade is happening are almost at the furthest points on the map they could have potentially been. Then a story that has a character traverse the ocean mostly on a small lake boat while uncounscious while it's supposed to be dangerous to be on the ocean.

Overall, it seems square enix had a few good small stories and they decided to stuff them together with a world another team created over Bravely Default's gameplay and never bothered trying to make each of these three parts fit coherently together. If you can ignore these inconsistencies, then it's a pretty good game, however, if you care about the game having any semblance of coherence between it's different parts, you're going to have problems with this game.

I'm going to use Castti's chapter 2 as an example.

 [spoiler]So, you travel to Sai on your quest to recover her Memories. You walk into the Village, a Village at War might i add, and immediately someone yells for help, and Castti being a healer wants to help. All good so far. HE DOES A FULL 180 ON HIS MINDSET AFTER BEING TOLD TO FETCH WATER AND FIREWOOD! He suddenly comes to realise that War is bad and then turns into an entirely different character that helps everyone. And it's so fucking jarring, because its not given the time to properly unfold. You kill a big bug and then randomly the War is over because the other Leader Guy goes to beg the king and the Chapter is over. The amount of words it took to describe this is about as much dialog as there is in the chapter that drives that plot forward. I want to start with saying that the story and gameplay are good, the problem is how the two don't work together and causes jarring discrepancies between the gameplay and the story.

From a gameplay perspective, this is mostly just Bravely Default's gameplay system, turn-based party combat since you'll have a party of 4 for the vast majority of the game unless you're actively trying a challenge run with less party members. As in Bravely Default, the gameplay is pretty good.

However, the story NEVER acknowledges that you're not just one character but a party. Each character's story acts as if the party didn't exist and that that character was alone. This shows in how there's no interaction between the characters during the story and the story even acts as if fights that are happening are 1v1 fights and, outside some fights involving certain characters whose path actions let's them duel NPCs, it's actually a fight between the enemy and your party which is insanely jarring. There are some interactions between party members in the form of party banter, small chats between generally 2 party members which sometimes somewhat relates to the current story but is often just for light hearted fun. There's also a handful of crosspaths, stories involving 2 specific characters, but they're short and there's not a lot of them.

Then there's also the world building which brings further inconsistencies with some NPCs acting like the world is big and it's a big deal to traverse a continent and even more so to cross the ocean between the 2 continents while the story and sidequests often act like the fast travel instant teleport is cannon. For example, you have a story that tells you an arms shipment is going to happen soon and needs to be stopped, but the place between where you learn of it and the place where the trade is happening are almost at the furthest points on the map they could have potentially been. Then a story that has a character traverse the ocean mostly on a small lake boat while uncounscious while it's supposed to be dangerous to be on the ocean.

Overall, it seems square enix had a few good small stories and they decided to stuff them together with a world another team created over Bravely Default's gameplay and never bothered trying to make each of these three parts fit coherently together. If you can ignore these inconsistencies, then it's a pretty good game, however, if you care about the game having any semblance of coherence between it's different parts, you're going to have problems with this game.

I'm going to mainly list the issues i have, but art, sound/music, combat, progression and even the writing itself are all wonderful and i very much like those.

Why is Throné travelling with...say Castti, holding off on her own, VERY URGENT, desires to help some random chick she happen to run into in the Desert for example. 

Each Chapter i completed came with...this curve, im gonna call it. I get intrigued, invested and then punched in the face with a brick. 

I'm going to use Castti's chapter 2 as an example.

 [spoiler]So, you travel to Sai on your quest to recover her Memories. You walk into the Village, a Village at War might i add, and immediately someone yells for help, and Castti being a healer wants to help. All good so far. You go to the field hospital, meet another Apothecary and the Soldier's mean, cold leader guy. Castti helps the other Healer with mending the wounded, then goes to the frontlines. She learns that the "Enemy" is injured and goes to help them, which is fair enough and makes sense, and Angy Leader Guy follows her. At this point, I figured we gonna have to fight him. You get to the injured, she yaps to Leader Guy to fetch Water and fire wood, which he declined. Then she yaps again and he is all of a sudden like "Oh...okay yes i will go grab it." HE DOES A FULL 180 ON HIS MINDSET AFTER BEING TOLD TO FETCH WATER AND FIREWOOD! He suddenly comes to realise that War is bad and then turns into an entirely different character that helps everyone. And it's so fucking jarring, because its not given the time to properly unfold. You kill a big bug and then randomly the War is over because the other Leader Guy goes to beg the king and the Chapter is over. The amount of words it took to describe this is about as much dialog as there is in the chapter that drives that plot forward. Maybe you can see my issue here...its fucking rushed, because its one of EIGHT Characters story, and just a chapter in it. This should be an entire act in a game.[/spoiler] 

After that, you kinda just stand there, open the Map to find the next chapter and "oh, well its 15 level above my current level, so i guess i do this Characters chapter instead." This shattered any immersion i had, any attachment. While it'd be dumb, I wouldn't care if i just grinded out levels and do one of the eight characters Story at a time...except then, for a large chunk of the chapters in each story, I'd be insanely over-leveled which would make the combat trivial. So instead, i dealt with being spoonfed bits and pieces of each story, which aren't exactly connected, with characters that realistically shouldn't be travelling together and instead do their own thing and...I don't know. It's still decent, the writing is good to a point where yes, the Chapters are insanely rushed in some cases, but i still fully understand what is going on. I'm just over this cycle of "Oh i can't wait to see whats next- Never mind, to low level, gotta do someone elses stuff first." This Cycle of being immersed in a story to just be ripped out of it. 

I know this is a mess to read but in conclusion...it lacks a main plot. Maybe there is one towards the end, maybe there isn't. I don't think I'll find out just yet. I'm over it. Can't believe im saying this but I'd prefer it if there was level scaling. Then i could just do one story after the other. It's like reading eight short stories at the same time, reading a chapter in one, then moving to another and so on all the way through and back to the first one.

I want to start with saying that the story and gameplay are good, the problem is how the two don't work together and causes jarring discrepancies between the gameplay and the story.

From a gameplay perspective, this is mostly just Bravely Default's gameplay system, turn-based party combat since you'll have a party of 4 for the vast majority of the game unless you're actively trying a challenge run with less party members. As in Bravely Default, the gameplay is pretty good.

However, the story NEVER acknowledges that you're not just one character but a party. Each character's story acts as if the party didn't exist and that that character was alone. This shows in how there's no interaction between the characters during the story and the story even acts as if fights that are happening are 1v1 fights and, outside some fights involving certain characters whose path actions let's them duel NPCs, it's actually a fight between the enemy and your party which is insanely jarring. There are some interactions between party members in the form of party banter, small chats between generally 2 party members which sometimes somewhat relates to the current story but is often just for light hearted fun. There's also a handful of crosspaths, stories involving 2 specific characters, but they're short and there's not a lot of them.

Then there's also the world building which brings further inconsistencies with some NPCs acting like the world is big and it's a big deal to traverse a continent and even more so to cross the ocean between the 2 continents while the story and sidequests often act like the fast travel instant teleport is cannon. For example, you have a story that tells you an arms shipment is going to happen soon and needs to be stopped, but the place between where you learn of it and the place where the trade is happening are almost at the furthest points on the map they could have potentially been. Then a story that has a character traverse the ocean mostly on a small lake boat while uncounscious while it's supposed to be dangerous to be on the ocean.

Overall, it seems square enix had a few good small stories and they decided to stuff them together with a world another team created over Bravely Default's gameplay and never bothered trying to make each of these three parts fit coherently together. If you can ignore these inconsistencies, then it's a pretty good game, however, if you care about the game having any semblance of coherence between it's different parts, you're going to have problems with this game.
